persona.name: PHILOSTRATE
persona.alias: master of the revels to Theseus.

persona.name: HIPPOLYTA
persona.alias: queen of the Amazons, betrothed to Theseus.

persona.name: HERMIA
persona.alias: daughter to Egeus, in love with Lysander.

persona.name: Other fairies attending their King and Queen.

scene.title: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour Draws on apace; four happy days bring in Another moon: but, O, methinks, how slow This old moon wanes! she lingers my desires, Like to a step-dame or a dowager Long withering out a young man revenue.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Happy be Theseus, our renowned duke!

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Thanks, good Egeus: what's the news with thee?

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Full of vexation come I, with complaint Against my child, my daughter Hermia. Stand forth, Demetrius. My noble lord, This man hath my consent to marry her. Stand forth, Lysander: and my gracious duke, This man hath bewitch'd the bosom of my child; Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes, And interchanged love-tokens with my child: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung, With feigning voice verses of feigning love, And stolen the impression of her fantasy With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gawds, conceits, Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats, messengers Of strong prevailment in unharden'd youth: With cunning hast thou filch'd my daughter's heart, Turn'd her obedience, which is due to me, To stubborn harshness: and, my gracious duke, Be it so she; will not here before your grace Consent to marry with Demetrius, I beg the ancient privilege of Athens, As she is mine, I may dispose of her: Which shall be either to this gentleman Or to her death, according to our law Immediately provided in that case.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: What say you, Hermia? be advised fair maid: To you your father should be as a god; One that composed your beauties, yea, and one To whom you are but as a form in wax By him imprinted and within his power To leave the figure or disfigure it. Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: So is Lysander.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I would my father look'd but with my eyes.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I do entreat your grace to pardon me. I know not by what power I am made bold, Nor how it may concern my modesty, In such a presence here to plead my thoughts; But I beseech your grace that I may know The worst that may befall me in this case, If I refuse to wed Demetrius.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Either to die the death or to abjure For ever the society of men. Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires; Know of your youth, examine well your blood, Whether, if you yield not to your father's choice, You can endure the livery of a nun, For aye to be in shady cloister mew'd, To live a barren sister all your life, Chanting faint hymns to the cold fruitless moon. Thrice-blessed they that master so their blood, To undergo such maiden pilgrimage; But earthlier happy is the rose distill'd, Than that which withering on the virgin thorn Grows, lives and dies in single blessedness.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord, Ere I will my virgin patent up Unto his lordship, whose unwished yoke My soul consents not to give sovereignty.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Take time to pause; and, by the nest new moon-- The sealing-day betwixt my love and me, For everlasting bond of fellowship-- Upon that day either prepare to die For disobedience to your father's will, Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would; Or on Diana's altar to protest For aye austerity and single life.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Relent, sweet Hermia: and, Lysander, yield Thy crazed title to my certain right.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: You have her father's love, Demetrius; Let me have Hermia's: do you marry him.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Scornful Lysander! true, he hath my love, And what is mine my love shall render him. And she is mine, and all my right of her I do estate unto Demetrius.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I am, my lord, as well derived as he, As well possess'd; my love is more than his; My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd, If not with vantage, as Demetrius'; And, which is more than all these boasts can be, I am beloved of beauteous Hermia: Why should not I then prosecute my right? Demetrius, I'll avouch it to his head, Made love to Nedar's daughter, Helena, And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, dotes, Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry, Upon this spotted and inconstant man.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I must confess that I have heard so much, And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof; But, being over-full of self-affairs, My mind did lose it. But, Demetrius, come; And come, Egeus; you shall go with me, I have some private schooling for you both. For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself To fit your fancies to your father's will; Or else the law of Athens yields you up-- Which by no means we may extenuate-- To death, or to a vow of single life. Come, my Hippolyta: what cheer, my love? Demetrius and Egeus, go along: I must employ you in some business Against our nuptial and confer with you Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.

speech.stagedir: Enter EGEUS, HERMIA, LYSANDER, and DEMETRIUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: With duty and desire we follow you.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: How now, my love! why is your cheek so pale? How chance the roses there do fade so fast?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Belike for want of rain, which I could well Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Ay me! for aught that I could ever read, Could ever hear by tale or history, The course of true love never did run smooth; But, either it was different in blood,--

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O cross! too high to be enthrall'd to low.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Or else misgraffed in respect of years,--

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O spite! too old to be engaged to young.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends,--

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O hell! to choose love by another's eyes.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Or, if there were a sympathy in choice, War, death, or sickness did lay siege to it, Making it momentany as a sound, Swift as a shadow, short as any dream; Brief as the lightning in the collied night, That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and earth, And ere a man hath power to say 'Behold!' The jaws of darkness do devour it up: So quick bright things come to confusion.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: If then true lovers have been ever cross'd, It stands as an edict in destiny: Then let us teach our trial patience, Because it is a customary cross, As due to love as thoughts and dreams and sighs, Wishes and tears, poor fancy's followers.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: A good persuasion: therefore, hear me, Hermia. I have a widow aunt, a dowager Of great revenue, and she hath no child: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues; And she respects me as her only son. There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee; And to that place the sharp Athenian law Cannot pursue us. If thou lovest me then, Steal forth thy father's house to-morrow night; And in the wood, a league without the town, Where I did meet thee once with Helena, To do observance to a morn of May, There will I stay for thee.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: My good Lysander! I swear to thee, by Cupid's strongest bow, By his best arrow with the golden head, By the simplicity of Venus' doves, By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves, And by that fire which burn'd the Carthage queen, When the false Troyan under sail was seen, By all the vows that ever men have broke, In number more than ever women spoke, In that same place thou hast appointed me, To-morrow truly will I meet with thee.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but LYSANDER and HERMIA
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Keep promise, love. Look, here comes Helena.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: God speed fair Helena! whither away?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Call you me fair? that fair again unsay. Demetrius loves your fair: O happy fair! Your eyes are lode-stars; and your tongue's sweet air More tuneable than lark to shepherd's ear, When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear. Sickness is catching: O, were favour so, Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go; My ear should catch your voice, my eye your eye, My tongue should catch your tongue's sweet melody. Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated, The rest I'd give to be to you translated. O, teach me how you look, and with what art You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O that my prayers could such affection move!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: The more I hate, the more he follows me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: The more I love, the more he hateth me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: None, but your beauty: would that fault were mine!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Take comfort: he no more shall see my face; Lysander and myself will fly this place. Before the time I did Lysander see, Seem'd Athens as a paradise to me: O, then, what graces in my love do dwell, That he hath turn'd a heaven unto a hell!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold: To-morrow night, when Phoebe doth behold Her silver visage in the watery glass, Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass, A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal, Through Athens' gates have we devised to steal.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: And in the wood, where often you and I Upon faint primrose-beds were wont to lie, Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet, There my Lysander and myself shall meet; And thence from Athens turn away our eyes, To seek new friends and stranger companies. Farewell, sweet playfellow: pray thou for us; And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius! Keep word, Lysander: we must starve our sight From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I will, my Hermia. Helena, adieu: As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: How happy some o'er other some can be! Through Athens I am thought as fair as she. But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so; He will not know what all but he do know: And as he errs, doting on Hermia's eyes, So I, admiring of his qualities: Things base and vile, folding no quantity, Love can transpose to form and dignity: Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind; And therefore is wing'd Cupid painted blind: Nor hath Love's mind of any judgement taste; Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste: And therefore is Love said to be a child, Because in choice he is so oft beguiled. As waggish boys in game themselves forswear, So the boy Love is perjured every where: For ere Demetrius look'd on Hermia's eyne, He hail'd down oaths that he was only mine; And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt, So he dissolved, and showers of oaths did melt. I will go tell him of fair Hermia's flight: Then to the wood will he to-morrow night Pursue her; and for this intelligence If I have thanks, it is a dear expense: But herein mean I to enrich my pain, To have his sight thither and back again.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Is all our company here?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: You were best to call them generally, man by man, according to the scrip.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Here is the scroll of every man's name, which is thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our interlude before the duke and the duchess, on his wedding-day at night.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow to a point.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Marry, our play is, The most lamentable comedy, and most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisby.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a merry. Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your actors by the scroll. Masters, spread yourselves.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: What is Pyramus? a lover, or a tyrant?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: A lover, that kills himself most gallant for love.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: That will ask some tears in the true performing of it: if I do it, let the audience look to their eyes; I will move storms, I will condole in some measure. To the rest: yet my chief humour is for a tyrant: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in, to make all split. The raging rocks And shivering shocks Shall break the locks Of prison gates; And Phibbus' car Shall shine from far And make and mar The foolish Fates. This was lofty! Now name the rest of the players. This is Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein; a lover is more condoling.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Here, Peter Quince.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Flute, you must take Thisby on you.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: What is Thisby? a wandering knight?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman; I have a beard coming.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: That's all one: you shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisby too, I'll speak in a monstrous little voice. 'Thisne, Thisne;' 'Ah, Pyramus, lover dear! thy Thisby dear, and lady dear!'

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: No, no; you must play Pyramus: and, Flute, you Thisby.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Well, proceed.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Robin Starveling, the tailor.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Here, Peter Quince.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother. Tom Snout, the tinker.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Here, Peter Quince.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: You, Pyramus' father: myself, Thisby's father: Snug, the joiner; you, the lion's part: and, I hope, here is a play fitted.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Have you the lion's part written? pray you, if it be, give it me, for I am slow of study.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Let me play the lion too: I will roar, that I will do any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar, that I will make the duke say 'Let him roar again, let him roar again.'

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: That would hang us, every mother's son.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: I grant you, friends, if that you should fright the ladies out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us: but I will aggravate my voice so that I will roar you as gently as any sucking dove; I will roar you an 'twere any nightingale.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: You can play no part but Pyramus; for Pyramus is a sweet-faced man; a proper man, as one shall see in a summer's day; a most lovely gentleman-like man: therefore you must needs play Pyramus.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best to play it in?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Why, what you will.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: I will discharge it in either your straw-colour beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your French-crown-colour beard, your perfect yellow.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and then you will play bare-faced. But, masters, here are your parts: and I am to entreat you, request you and desire you, to con them by to-morrow night; and meet me in the palace wood, a mile without the town, by moonlight; there will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city, we shall be dogged with company, and our devices known. In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties, such as our play wants. I pray you, fail me not.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: We will meet; and there we may rehearse most obscenely and courageously. Take pains; be perfect: adieu.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: At the duke's oak we meet.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Enough; hold or cut bow-strings.

scene.title: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: How now, spirit! whither wander you?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Over hill, over dale, Thorough bush, thorough brier, Over park, over pale, Thorough flood, thorough fire, I do wander everywhere, Swifter than the moon's sphere; And I serve the fairy queen, To dew her orbs upon the green. The cowslips tall her pensioners be: In their gold coats spots you see; Those be rubies, fairy favours, In those freckles live their savours: I must go seek some dewdrops here And hang a pearl in every cowslip's ear. Farewell, thou lob of spirits; I'll be gone: Our queen and all our elves come here anon.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: The king doth keep his revels here to-night: Take heed the queen come not within his sight; For Oberon is passing fell and wrath, Because that she as her attendant hath A lovely boy, stolen from an Indian king; She never had so sweet a changeling; And jealous Oberon would have the child Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild; But she perforce withholds the loved boy, Crowns him with flowers and makes him all her joy: And now they never meet in grove or green, By fountain clear, or spangled starlight sheen, But, they do square, that all their elves for fear Creep into acorn-cups and hide them there.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Either I mistake your shape and making quite, Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite Call'd Robin Goodfellow: are not you he That frights the maidens of the villagery; Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern And bootless make the breathless housewife churn; And sometime make the drink to bear no barm; Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm? Those that Hobgoblin call you and sweet Puck, You do their work, and they shall have good luck: Are not you he?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Thou speak'st aright; I am that merry wanderer of the night. I jest to Oberon and make him smile When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile, Neighing in likeness of a filly foal: And sometime lurk I in a gossip's bowl, In very likeness of a roasted crab, And when she drinks, against her lips I bob And on her wither'd dewlap pour the ale. The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale, Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me; Then slip I from her bum, down topples she, And 'tailor' cries, and falls into a cough; And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh, And waxen in their mirth and neeze and swear A merrier hour was never wasted there. But, room, fairy! here comes Oberon.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from opposite sides, a Fairy, and PUCK
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: What, jealous Oberon! Fairies, skip hence: I have forsworn his bed and company.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Tarry, rash wanton: am not I thy lord?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Then I must be thy lady: but I know When thou hast stolen away from fairy land, And in the shape of Corin sat all day, Playing on pipes of corn and versing love To amorous Phillida. Why art thou here, Come from the farthest Steppe of India? But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon, Your buskin'd mistress and your warrior love, To Theseus must be wedded, and you come To give their bed joy and prosperity.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: How canst thou thus for shame, Titania, Glance at my credit with Hippolyta, Knowing I know thy love to Theseus? Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night From Perigenia, whom he ravished? And make him with fair AEgle break his faith, With Ariadne and Antiopa?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: These are the forgeries of jealousy: And never, since the middle summer's spring, Met we on hill, in dale, forest or mead, By paved fountain or by rushy brook, Or in the beached margent of the sea, To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind, But with thy brawls thou hast disturb'd our sport. Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain, As in revenge, have suck'd up from the sea Contagious fogs; which falling in the land Have every pelting river made so proud That they have overborne their continents: The ox hath therefore stretch'd his yoke in vain, The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn Hath rotted ere his youth attain'd a beard; The fold stands empty in the drowned field, And crows are fatted with the murrion flock; The nine men's morris is fill'd up with mud, And the quaint mazes in the wanton green For lack of tread are undistinguishable: The human mortals want their winter here; No night is now with hymn or carol blest: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods, Pale in her anger, washes all the air, That rheumatic diseases do abound: And thorough this distemperature we see The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts Far in the fresh lap of the crimson rose, And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds Is, as in mockery, set: the spring, the summer, The childing autumn, angry winter, change Their wonted liveries, and the mazed world, By their increase, now knows not which is which: And this same progeny of evils comes From our debate, from our dissension; We are their parents and original.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Do you amend it then; it lies in you: Why should Titania cross her Oberon? I do but beg a little changeling boy, To be my henchman.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Set your heart at rest: The fairy land buys not the child of me. His mother was a votaress of my order: And, in the spiced Indian air, by night, Full often hath she gossip'd by my side, And sat with me on Neptune's yellow sands, Marking the embarked traders on the flood, When we have laugh'd to see the sails conceive And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind; Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait Following,--her womb then rich with my young squire,-- Would imitate, and sail upon the land, To fetch me trifles, and return again, As from a voyage, rich with merchandise. But she, being mortal, of that boy did die; And for her sake do I rear up her boy, And for her sake I will not part with him.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: How long within this wood intend you stay?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Perchance till after Theseus' wedding-day. If you will patiently dance in our round And see our moonlight revels, go with us; If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Give me that boy, and I will go with thee.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, OBERON, with his train; from the other, TITANIA, with hers
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Not for thy fairy kingdom. Fairies, away! We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Well, go thy way: thou shalt not from this grove Till I torment thee for this injury. My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememberest Since once I sat upon a promontory, And heard a mermaid on a dolphin's back Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath That the rude sea grew civil at her song And certain stars shot madly from their spheres, To hear the sea-maid's music.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: I remember.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: That very time I saw, but thou couldst not, Flying between the cold moon and the earth, Cupid all arm'd: a certain aim he took At a fair vestal throned by the west, And loosed his love-shaft smartly from his bow, As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts; But I might see young Cupid's fiery shaft Quench'd in the chaste beams of the watery moon, And the imperial votaress passed on, In maiden meditation, fancy-free. Yet mark'd I where the bolt of Cupid fell: It fell upon a little western flower, Before milk-white, now purple with love's wound, And maidens call it love-in-idleness. Fetch me that flower; the herb I shew'd thee once: The juice of it on sleeping eye-lids laid Will make or man or woman madly dote Upon the next live creature that it sees. Fetch me this herb; and be thou here again Ere the leviathan can swim a league.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: I'll put a girdle round about the earth In forty minutes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Having once this juice, I'll watch Titania when she is asleep, And drop the liquor of it in her eyes. The next thing then she waking looks upon, Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull, On meddling monkey, or on busy ape, She shall pursue it with the soul of love: And ere I take this charm from off her sight, As I can take it with another herb, I'll make her render up her page to me. But who comes here? I am invisible; And I will overhear their conference.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: I love thee not, therefore pursue me not. Where is Lysander and fair Hermia? The one I'll slay, the other slayeth me. Thou told'st me they were stolen unto this wood; And here am I, and wode within this wood, Because I cannot meet my Hermia. Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant; But yet you draw not iron, for my heart Is true as steel: leave you your power to draw, And I shall have no power to follow you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Do I entice you? do I speak you fair? Or, rather, do I not in plainest truth Tell you, I do not, nor I cannot love you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: And even for that do I love you the more. I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius, The more you beat me, I will fawn on you: Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me, Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave, Unworthy as I am, to follow you. What worser place can I beg in your love,-- And yet a place of high respect with me,-- Than to be used as you use your dog?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit; For I am sick when I do look on thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: And I am sick when I look not on you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: You do impeach your modesty too much, To leave the city and commit yourself Into the hands of one that loves you not; To trust the opportunity of night And the ill counsel of a desert place With the rich worth of your virginity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Your virtue is my privilege: for that It is not night when I do see your face, Therefore I think I am not in the night; Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company, For you in my respect are all the world: Then how can it be said I am alone, When all the world is here to look on me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes, And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: The wildest hath not such a heart as you. Run when you will, the story shall be changed: Apollo flies, and Daphne holds the chase; The dove pursues the griffin; the mild hind Makes speed to catch the tiger; bootless speed, When cowardice pursues and valour flies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: I will not stay thy questions; let me go: Or, if thou follow me, do not believe But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field, You do me mischief. Fie, Demetrius! Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex: We cannot fight for love, as men may do; We should be wood and were not made to woo. I'll follow thee and make a heaven of hell, To die upon the hand I love so well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Fare thee well, nymph: ere he do leave this grove, Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love. Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Ay, there it is.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: I pray thee, give it me. I know a bank where the wild thyme blows, Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows, Quite over-canopied with luscious woodbine, With sweet musk-roses and with eglantine: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night, Lull'd in these flowers with dances and delight; And there the snake throws her enamell'd skin, Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in: And with the juice of this I'll streak her eyes, And make her full of hateful fantasies. Take thou some of it, and seek through this grove: A sweet Athenian lady is in love With a disdainful youth: anoint his eyes; But do it when the next thing he espies May be the lady: thou shalt know the man By the Athenian garments he hath on. Effect it with some care, that he may prove More fond on her than she upon her love: And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A wood near Athens.
speech.text: Fear not, my lord, your servant shall do so.

scene.title: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Hence, away! now all is well: One aloof stand sentinel.

speech.stagedir: Enter OBERON and squeezes the flower on TITANIA's eyelids
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: What thou seest when thou dost wake, Do it for thy true-love take, Love and languish for his sake: Be it ounce, or cat, or bear, Pard, or boar with bristled hair, In thy eye that shall appear When thou wakest, it is thy dear: Wake when some vile thing is near.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Fair love, you faint with wandering in the wood; And to speak troth, I have forgot our way: We'll rest us, Hermia, if you think it good, And tarry for the comfort of the day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Be it so, Lysander: find you out a bed; For I upon this bank will rest my head.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: One turf shall serve as pillow for us both; One heart, one bed, two bosoms and one troth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Nay, good Lysander; for my sake, my dear, Lie further off yet, do not lie so near.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Lysander riddles very prettily: Now much beshrew my manners and my pride, If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied. But, gentle friend, for love and courtesy Lie further off; in human modesty, Such separation as may well be said Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid, So far be distant; and, good night, sweet friend: Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: With half that wish the wisher's eyes be press'd!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Through the forest have I gone. But Athenian found I none, On whose eyes I might approve This flower's force in stirring love. Night and silence.--Who is here? Weeds of Athens he doth wear: This is he, my master said, Despised the Athenian maid; And here the maiden, sleeping sound, On the dank and dirty ground. Pretty soul! she durst not lie Near this lack-love, this kill-courtesy. Churl, upon thy eyes I throw All the power this charm doth owe. When thou wakest, let love forbid Sleep his seat on thy eyelid: So awake when I am gone; For I must now to Oberon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O, wilt thou darkling leave me? do not so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Stay, on thy peril: I alone will go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O, I am out of breath in this fond chase! The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace. Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies; For she hath blessed and attractive eyes. How came her eyes so bright? Not with salt tears: If so, my eyes are oftener wash'd than hers. No, no, I am as ugly as a bear; For beasts that meet me run away for fear: Therefore no marvel though Demetrius Do, as a monster fly my presence thus. What wicked and dissembling glass of mine Made me compare with Hermia's sphery eyne? But who is here? Lysander! on the ground! Dead? or asleep? I see no blood, no wound. Lysander if you live, good sir, awake.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: And run through fire I will for thy sweet sake. Transparent Helena! Nature shows art, That through thy bosom makes me see thy heart. Where is Demetrius? O, how fit a word Is that vile name to perish on my sword!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Do not say so, Lysander; say not so What though he love your Hermia? Lord, what though? Yet Hermia still loves you: then be content.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Content with Hermia! No; I do repent The tedious minutes I with her have spent. Not Hermia but Helena I love: Who will not change a raven for a dove? The will of man is by his reason sway'd; And reason says you are the worthier maid. Things growing are not ripe until their season So I, being young, till now ripe not to reason; And touching now the point of human skill, Reason becomes the marshal to my will And leads me to your eyes, where I o'erlook Love's stories written in love's richest book.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Wherefore was I to this keen mockery born? When at your hands did I deserve this scorn? Is't not enough, is't not enough, young man, That I did never, no, nor never can, Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye, But you must flout my insufficiency? Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do, In such disdainful manner me to woo. But fare you well: perforce I must confess I thought you lord of more true gentleness. O, that a lady, of one man refused. Should of another therefore be abused!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: She sees not Hermia. Hermia, sleep thou there: And never mayst thou come Lysander near! For as a surfeit of the sweetest things The deepest loathing to the stomach brings, Or as tie heresies that men do leave Are hated most of those they did deceive, So thou, my surfeit and my heresy, Of all be hated, but the most of me! And, all my powers, address your love and might To honour Helen and to be her knight!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Help me, Lysander, help me! do thy best To pluck this crawling serpent from my breast! Ay me, for pity! what a dream was here! Lysander, look how I do quake with fear: Methought a serpent eat my heart away, And you sat smiling at his cruel pray. Lysander! what, removed? Lysander! lord! What, out of hearing? gone? no sound, no word? Alack, where are you speak, an if you hear; Speak, of all loves! I swoon almost with fear. No? then I well perceive you all not nigh Either death or you I'll find immediately.

scene.title: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Are we all met?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Pat, pat; and here's a marvellous convenient place for our rehearsal. This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house; and we will do it in action as we will do it before the duke.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Peter Quince,--

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: What sayest thou, bully Bottom?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisby that will never please. First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself; which the ladies cannot abide. How answer you that?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: By'r lakin, a parlous fear.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Not a whit: I have a device to make all well. Write me a prologue; and let the prologue seem to say, we will do no harm with our swords, and that Pyramus is not killed indeed; and, for the more better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver: this will put them out of fear.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Well, we will have such a prologue; and it shall be written in eight and six.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: No, make it two more; let it be written in eight and eight.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I fear it, I promise you.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Masters, you ought to consider with yourselves: to bring in--God shield us!--a lion among ladies, is a most dreadful thing; for there is not a more fearful wild-fowl than your lion living; and we ought to look to 't.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion's neck: and he himself must speak through, saying thus, or to the same defect,--'Ladies,'--or 'Fair-ladies--I would wish You,'--or 'I would request you,'--or 'I would entreat you,--not to fear, not to tremble: my life for yours. If you think I come hither as a lion, it were pity of my life: no I am no such thing; I am a man as other men are;' and there indeed let him name his name, and tell them plainly he is Snug the joiner.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: A calendar, a calendar! look in the almanac; find out moonshine, find out moonshine.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Yes, it doth shine that night.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Why, then may you leave a casement of the great chamber window, where we play, open, and the moon may shine in at the casement.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Ay; or else one must come in with a bush of thorns and a lanthorn, and say he comes to disfigure, or to present, the person of Moonshine. Then, there is another thing: we must have a wall in the great chamber; for Pyramus and Thisby says the story, did talk through the chink of a wall.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: You can never bring in a wall. What say you, Bottom?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Some man or other must present Wall: and let him have some plaster, or some loam, or some rough-cast about him, to signify wall; and let him hold his fingers thus, and through that cranny shall Pyramus and Thisby whisper.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: If that may be, then all is well. Come, sit down, every mother's son, and rehearse your parts. Pyramus, you begin: when you have spoken your speech, enter into that brake: and so every one according to his cue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: What hempen home-spuns have we swaggering here, So near the cradle of the fairy queen? What, a play toward! I'll be an auditor; An actor too, perhaps, if I see cause.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Speak, Pyramus. Thisby, stand forth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Thisby, the flowers of odious savours sweet,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Odours, odours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: --odours savours sweet: So hath thy breath, my dearest Thisby dear. But hark, a voice! stay thou but here awhile, And by and by I will to thee appear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: A stranger Pyramus than e'er played here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Must I speak now?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Ay, marry, must you; for you must understand he goes but to see a noise that he heard, and is to come again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Most radiant Pyramus, most lily-white of hue, Of colour like the red rose on triumphant brier, Most brisky juvenal and eke most lovely Jew, As true as truest horse that yet would never tire, I'll meet thee, Pyramus, at Ninny's tomb.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: 'Ninus' tomb,' man: why, you must not speak that yet; that you answer to Pyramus: you speak all your part at once, cues and all Pyramus enter: your cue is past; it is, 'never tire.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: O,--As true as truest horse, that yet would never tire.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter PUCK, and BOTTOM with an ass's head
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: If I were fair, Thisby, I were only thine.

speech.stagedir: Re-enter PUCK, and BOTTOM with an ass's head
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: O monstrous! O strange! we are haunted. Pray, masters! fly, masters! Help!

speech.stagedir: Exeunt QUINCE, SNUG, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I'll follow you, I'll lead you about a round, Through bog, through bush, through brake, through brier: Sometime a horse I'll be, sometime a hound, A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire; And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn, Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Why do they run away? this is a knavery of them to make me afeard.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: O Bottom, thou art changed! what do I see on thee?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: What do you see? you see an asshead of your own, do you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Bless thee, Bottom! bless thee! thou art translated.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I see their knavery: this is to make an ass of me; to fright me, if they could. But I will not stir from this place, do what they can: I will walk up and down here, and I will sing, that they shall hear I am not afraid. The ousel cock so black of hue, With orange-tawny bill, The throstle with his note so true, The wren with little quill,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: What angel wakes me from my flowery bed?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: The finch, the sparrow and the lark, The plain-song cuckoo gray, Whose note full many a man doth mark, And dares not answer nay;-- for, indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird? who would give a bird the lie, though he cry 'cuckoo' never so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that: and yet, to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together now-a-days; the more the pity that some honest neighbours will not make them friends. Nay, I can gleek upon occasion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Not so, neither: but if I had wit enough to get out of this wood, I have enough to serve mine own turn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Ready.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: And I.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: And I.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: And I.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Where shall we go?

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Hail, mortal!

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Hail!

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Hail!

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Hail!

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I cry your worship's mercy, heartily: I beseech your worship's name.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Cobweb.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I shall desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Cobweb: if I cut my finger, I shall make bold with you. Your name, honest gentleman?

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Peaseblossom.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I pray you, commend me to Mistress Squash, your mother, and to Master Peascod, your father. Good Master Peaseblossom, I shall desire you of more acquaintance too. Your name, I beseech you, sir?

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Mustardseed.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Good Master Mustardseed, I know your patience well: that same cowardly, giant-like ox-beef hath devoured many a gentleman of your house: I promise you your kindred had made my eyes water ere now. I desire your more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.

speech.stagedir: Enter PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The wood. TITANIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Come, wait upon him; lead him to my bower. The moon methinks looks with a watery eye; And when she weeps, weeps every little flower, Lamenting some enforced chastity. Tie up my love's tongue bring him silently.

scene.title: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I wonder if Titania be awaked; Then, what it was that next came in her eye, Which she must dote on in extremity. Here comes my messenger. How now, mad spirit! What night-rule now about this haunted grove?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: My mistress with a monster is in love. Near to her close and consecrated bower, While she was in her dull and sleeping hour, A crew of patches, rude mechanicals, That work for bread upon Athenian stalls, Were met together to rehearse a play Intended for great Theseus' nuptial-day. The shallowest thick-skin of that barren sort, Who Pyramus presented, in their sport Forsook his scene and enter'd in a brake When I did him at this advantage take, An ass's nole I fixed on his head: Anon his Thisbe must be answered, And forth my mimic comes. When they him spy, As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye, Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort, Rising and cawing at the gun's report, Sever themselves and madly sweep the sky, So, at his sight, away his fellows fly; And, at our stamp, here o'er and o'er one falls; He murder cries and help from Athens calls. Their sense thus weak, lost with their fears thus strong, Made senseless things begin to do them wrong; For briers and thorns at their apparel snatch; Some sleeves, some hats, from yielders all things catch. I led them on in this distracted fear, And left sweet Pyramus translated there: When in that moment, so it came to pass, Titania waked and straightway loved an ass.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: This falls out better than I could devise. But hast thou yet latch'd the Athenian's eyes With the love-juice, as I did bid thee do?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I took him sleeping,--that is finish'd too,-- And the Athenian woman by his side: That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Stand close: this is the same Athenian.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: This is the woman, but not this the man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O, why rebuke you him that loves you so? Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Now I but chide; but I should use thee worse, For thou, I fear, hast given me cause to curse, If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep, Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep, And kill me too. The sun was not so true unto the day As he to me: would he have stolen away From sleeping Hermia? I'll believe as soon This whole earth may be bored and that the moon May through the centre creep and so displease Her brother's noontide with Antipodes. It cannot be but thou hast murder'd him; So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: So should the murder'd look, and so should I, Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty: Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear, As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: What's this to my Lysander? where is he? Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Out, dog! out, cur! thou drivest me past the bounds Of maiden's patience. Hast thou slain him, then? Henceforth be never number'd among men! O, once tell true, tell true, even for my sake! Durst thou have look'd upon him being awake, And hast thou kill'd him sleeping? O brave touch! Could not a worm, an adder, do so much? An adder did it; for with doubler tongue Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: An if I could, what should I get therefore?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: A privilege never to see me more. And from thy hated presence part I so: See me no more, whether he be dead or no.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: There is no following her in this fierce vein: Here therefore for a while I will remain. So sorrow's heaviness doth heavier grow For debt that bankrupt sleep doth sorrow owe: Which now in some slight measure it will pay, If for his tender here I make some stay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: What hast thou done? thou hast mistaken quite And laid the love-juice on some true-love's sight: Of thy misprision must perforce ensue Some true love turn'd and not a false turn'd true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Then fate o'er-rules, that, one man holding troth, A million fail, confounding oath on oath.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: About the wood go swifter than the wind, And Helena of Athens look thou find: All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer, With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear: By some illusion see thou bring her here: I'll charm his eyes against she do appear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I go, I go; look how I go, Swifter than arrow from the Tartar's bow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Flower of this purple dye, Hit with Cupid's archery, Sink in apple of his eye. When his love he doth espy, Let her shine as gloriously As the Venus of the sky. When thou wakest, if she be by, Beg of her for remedy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Captain of our fairy band, Helena is here at hand; And the youth, mistook by me, Pleading for a lover's fee. Shall we their fond pageant see? Lord, what fools these mortals be!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Stand aside: the noise they make Will cause Demetrius to awake.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn? Scorn and derision never come in tears: Look, when I vow, I weep; and vows so born, In their nativity all truth appears. How can these things in me seem scorn to you, Bearing the badge of faith, to prove them true?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: You do advance your cunning more and more. When truth kills truth, O devilish-holy fray! These vows are Hermia's: will you give her o'er? Weigh oath with oath, and you will nothing weigh: Your vows to her and me, put in two scales, Will even weigh, and both as light as tales.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I had no judgment when to her I swore.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o'er.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O Helena, goddess, nymph, perfect, divine! To what, my love, shall I compare thine eyne? Crystal is muddy. O, how ripe in show Thy lips, those kissing cherries, tempting grow! That pure congealed white, high Taurus snow, Fann'd with the eastern wind, turns to a crow When thou hold'st up thy hand: O, let me kiss This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O spite! O hell! I see you all are bent To set against me for your merriment: If you we re civil and knew courtesy, You would not do me thus much injury. Can you not hate me, as I know you do, But you must join in souls to mock me too? If you were men, as men you are in show, You would not use a gentle lady so; To vow, and swear, and superpraise my parts, When I am sure you hate me with your hearts. You both are rivals, and love Hermia; And now both rivals, to mock Helena: A trim exploit, a manly enterprise, To conjure tears up in a poor maid's eyes With your derision! none of noble sort Would so offend a virgin, and extort A poor soul's patience, all to make you sport.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Never did mockers waste more idle breath.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Lysander, keep thy Hermia; I will none: If e'er I loved her, all that love is gone. My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourn'd, And now to Helen is it home return'd, There to remain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Helen, it is not so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Disparage not the faith thou dost not know, Lest, to thy peril, thou aby it dear. Look, where thy love comes; yonder is thy dear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Dark night, that from the eye his function takes, The ear more quick of apprehension makes; Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense, It pays the hearing double recompense. Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found; Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Why should he stay, whom love doth press to go?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: What love could press Lysander from my side?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Lysander's love, that would not let him bide, Fair Helena, who more engilds the night Than all you fiery oes and eyes of light. Why seek'st thou me? could not this make thee know, The hate I bear thee made me leave thee so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: You speak not as you think: it cannot be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Lo, she is one of this confederacy! Now I perceive they have conjoin'd all three To fashion this false sport, in spite of me. Injurious Hermia! most ungrateful maid! Have you conspired, have you with these contrived To bait me with this foul derision? Is all the counsel that we two have shared, The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent, When we have chid the hasty-footed time For parting us,--O, is it all forgot? All school-days' friendship, childhood innocence? We, Hermia, like two artificial gods, Have with our needles created both one flower, Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion, Both warbling of one song, both in one key, As if our hands, our sides, voices and minds, Had been incorporate. So we grow together, Like to a double cherry, seeming parted, But yet an union in partition; Two lovely berries moulded on one stem; So, with two seeming bodies, but one heart; Two of the first, like coats in heraldry, Due but to one and crowned with one crest. And will you rent our ancient love asunder, To join with men in scorning your poor friend? It is not friendly, 'tis not maidenly: Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it, Though I alone do feel the injury.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I am amazed at your passionate words. I scorn you not: it seems that you scorn me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn, To follow me and praise my eyes and face? And made your other love, Demetrius, Who even but now did spurn me with his foot, To call me goddess, nymph, divine and rare, Precious, celestial? Wherefore speaks he this To her he hates? and wherefore doth Lysander Deny your love, so rich within his soul, And tender me, forsooth, affection, But by your setting on, by your consent? What thought I be not so in grace as you, So hung upon with love, so fortunate, But miserable most, to love unloved? This you should pity rather than despise.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I understand not what you mean by this.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Ay, do, persever, counterfeit sad looks, Make mouths upon me when I turn my back; Wink each at other; hold the sweet jest up: This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled. If you have any pity, grace, or manners, You would not make me such an argument. But fare ye well: 'tis partly my own fault; Which death or absence soon shall remedy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Stay, gentle Helena; hear my excuse: My love, my life my soul, fair Helena!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O excellent!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Sweet, do not scorn her so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: If she cannot entreat, I can compel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat: Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers. Helen, I love thee; by my life, I do: I swear by that which I will lose for thee, To prove him false that says I love thee not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I say I love thee more than he can do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: If thou say so, withdraw, and prove it too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Quick, come!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Lysander, whereto tends all this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Away, you Ethiope!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: No, no; he'll Seem to break loose; take on as you would follow, But yet come not: you are a tame man, go!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Hang off, thou cat, thou burr! vile thing, let loose, Or I will shake thee from me like a serpent!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Why are you grown so rude? what change is this? Sweet love,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Thy love! out, tawny Tartar, out! Out, loathed medicine! hated potion, hence!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Do you not jest?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Yes, sooth; and so do you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I would I had your bond, for I perceive A weak bond holds you: I'll not trust your word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: What, should I hurt her, strike her, kill her dead? Although I hate her, I'll not harm her so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: What, can you do me greater harm than hate? Hate me! wherefore? O me! what news, my love! Am not I Hermia? are not you Lysander? I am as fair now as I was erewhile. Since night you loved me; yet since night you left me: Why, then you left me--O, the gods forbid!-- In earnest, shall I say?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O me! you juggler! you canker-blossom! You thief of love! what, have you come by night And stolen my love's heart from him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Fine, i'faith! Have you no modesty, no maiden shame, No touch of bashfulness? What, will you tear Impatient answers from my gentle tongue? Fie, fie! you counterfeit, you puppet, you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen, Let her not hurt me: I was never curst; I have no gift at all in shrewishness; I am a right maid for my cowardice: Let her not strike me. You perhaps may think, Because she is something lower than myself, That I can match her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Lower! hark, again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Good Hermia, do not be so bitter with me. I evermore did love you, Hermia, Did ever keep your counsels, never wrong'd you; Save that, in love unto Demetrius, I told him of your stealth unto this wood. He follow'd you; for love I follow'd him; But he hath chid me hence and threaten'd me To strike me, spurn me, nay, to kill me too: And now, so you will let me quiet go, To Athens will I bear my folly back And follow you no further: let me go: You see how simple and how fond I am.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Why, get you gone: who is't that hinders you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: A foolish heart, that I leave here behind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: What, with Lysander?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: With Demetrius.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Be not afraid; she shall not harm thee, Helena.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: No, sir, she shall not, though you take her part.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: 'Little' again! nothing but 'low' and 'little'! Why will you suffer her to flout me thus? Let me come to her.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: You are too officious In her behalf that scorns your services. Let her alone: speak not of Helena; Take not her part; for, if thou dost intend Never so little show of love to her, Thou shalt aby it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Follow! nay, I'll go with thee, cheek by jole.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: You, mistress, all this coil is 'long of you: Nay, go not back.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I will not trust you, I, Nor longer stay in your curst company. Your hands than mine are quicker for a fray, My legs are longer though, to run away.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I am amazed, and know not what to say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: This is thy negligence: still thou mistakest, Or else committ'st thy knaveries wilfully.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Believe me, king of shadows, I mistook. Did not you tell me I should know the man By the Athenian garment be had on? And so far blameless proves my enterprise, That I have 'nointed an Athenian's eyes; And so far am I glad it so did sort As this their jangling I esteem a sport.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
