speech.text: Thou see'st these lovers seek a place to fight: Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night; The starry welkin cover thou anon With drooping fog as black as Acheron, And lead these testy rivals so astray As one come not within another's way. Like to Lysander sometime frame thy tongue, Then stir Demetrius up with bitter wrong; And sometime rail thou like Demetrius; And from each other look thou lead them thus, Till o'er their brows death-counterfeiting sleep With leaden legs and batty wings doth creep: Then crush this herb into Lysander's eye; Whose liquor hath this virtuous property, To take from thence all error with his might, And make his eyeballs roll with wonted sight. When they next wake, all this derision Shall seem a dream and fruitless vision, And back to Athens shall the lovers wend, With league whose date till death shall never end. Whiles I in this affair do thee employ, I'll to my queen and beg her Indian boy; And then I will her charmed eye release From monster's view, and all things shall be peace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: My fairy lord, this must be done with haste, For night's swift dragons cut the clouds full fast, And yonder shines Aurora's harbinger; At whose approach, ghosts, wandering here and there, Troop home to churchyards: damned spirits all, That in crossways and floods have burial, Already to their wormy beds are gone; For fear lest day should look their shames upon, They willfully themselves exile from light And must for aye consort with black-brow'd night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: But we are spirits of another sort: I with the morning's love have oft made sport, And, like a forester, the groves may tread, Even till the eastern gate, all fiery-red, Opening on Neptune with fair blessed beams, Turns into yellow gold his salt green streams. But, notwithstanding, haste; make no delay: We may effect this business yet ere day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Up and down, up and down, I will lead them up and down: I am fear'd in field and town: Goblin, lead them up and down. Here comes one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Where art thou, proud Demetrius? speak thou now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Here, villain; drawn and ready. Where art thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: I will be with thee straight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Follow me, then, To plainer ground.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Lysander! speak again: Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled? Speak! In some bush? Where dost thou hide thy head?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Thou coward, art thou bragging to the stars, Telling the bushes that thou look'st for wars, And wilt not come? Come, recreant; come, thou child; I'll whip thee with a rod: he is defiled That draws a sword on thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Yea, art thou there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Follow my voice: we'll try no manhood here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: He goes before me and still dares me on: When I come where he calls, then he is gone. The villain is much lighter-heel'd than I: I follow'd fast, but faster he did fly; That fallen am I in dark uneven way, And here will rest me. Come, thou gentle day! For if but once thou show me thy grey light, I'll find Demetrius and revenge this spite.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Ho, ho, ho! Coward, why comest thou not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Abide me, if thou darest; for well I wot Thou runn'st before me, shifting every place, And darest not stand, nor look me in the face. Where art thou now?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Come hither: I am here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Nay, then, thou mock'st me. Thou shalt buy this dear, If ever I thy face by daylight see: Now, go thy way. Faintness constraineth me To measure out my length on this cold bed. By day's approach look to be visited.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: O weary night, O long and tedious night, Abate thy hour! Shine comforts from the east, That I may back to Athens by daylight, From these that my poor company detest: And sleep, that sometimes shuts up sorrow's eye, Steal me awhile from mine own company.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Yet but three? Come one more; Two of both kinds make up four. Here she comes, curst and sad: Cupid is a knavish lad, Thus to make poor females mad.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: Never so weary, never so in woe, Bedabbled with the dew and torn with briers, I can no further crawl, no further go; My legs can keep no pace with my desires. Here will I rest me till the break of day. Heavens shield Lysander, if they mean a fray!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Another part of the wood.
speech.text: On the ground Sleep sound: I'll apply To your eye, Gentle lover, remedy. When thou wakest, Thou takest True delight In the sight Of thy former lady's eye: And the country proverb known, That every man should take his own, In your waking shall be shown: Jack shall have Jill; Nought shall go ill; The man shall have his mare again, and all shall be well.

scene.title: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Come, sit thee down upon this flowery bed, While I thy amiable cheeks do coy, And stick musk-roses in thy sleek smooth head, And kiss thy fair large ears, my gentle joy.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Where's Peaseblossom?

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Ready.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Scratch my head Peaseblossom. Where's Mounsieur Cobweb?

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Ready.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Mounsieur Cobweb, good mounsieur, get you your weapons in your hand, and kill me a red-hipped humble-bee on the top of a thistle; and, good mounsieur, bring me the honey-bag. Do not fret yourself too much in the action, mounsieur; and, good mounsieur, have a care the honey-bag break not; I would be loath to have you overflown with a honey-bag, signior. Where's Mounsieur Mustardseed?

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Ready.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Give me your neaf, Mounsieur Mustardseed. Pray you, leave your courtesy, good mounsieur.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: What's your Will?

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Nothing, good mounsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch. I must to the barber's, monsieur; for methinks I am marvellous hairy about the face; and I am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me, I must scratch.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: What, wilt thou hear some music, my sweet love?

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I have a reasonable good ear in music. Let's have the tongs and the bones.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Truly, a peck of provender: I could munch your good dry oats. Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle of hay: good hay, sweet hay, hath no fellow.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I have a venturous fairy that shall seek The squirrel's hoard, and fetch thee new nuts.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas. But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me: I have an exposition of sleep come upon me.

speech.stagedir: Enter TITANIA and BOTTOM; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED, and other Fairies attending; OBERON behind unseen
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms. Fairies, begone, and be all ways away. So doth the woodbine the sweet honeysuckle Gently entwist; the female ivy so Enrings the barky fingers of the elm. O, how I love thee! how I dote on thee!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Welcome, good Robin. See'st thou this sweet sight? Her dotage now I do begin to pity: For, meeting her of late behind the wood, Seeking sweet favours from this hateful fool, I did upbraid her and fall out with her; For she his hairy temples then had rounded With a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers; And that same dew, which sometime on the buds Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls, Stood now within the pretty flowerets' eyes Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail. When I had at my pleasure taunted her And she in mild terms begg'd my patience, I then did ask of her her changeling child; Which straight she gave me, and her fairy sent To bear him to my bower in fairy land. And now I have the boy, I will undo This hateful imperfection of her eyes: And, gentle Puck, take this transformed scalp From off the head of this Athenian swain; That, he awaking when the other do, May all to Athens back again repair And think no more of this night's accidents But as the fierce vexation of a dream. But first I will release the fairy queen. Be as thou wast wont to be; See as thou wast wont to see: Dian's bud o'er Cupid's flower Hath such force and blessed power. Now, my Titania; wake you, my sweet queen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: My Oberon! what visions have I seen! Methought I was enamour'd of an ass.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: There lies your love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: How came these things to pass? O, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Silence awhile. Robin, take off this head. Titania, music call; and strike more dead Than common sleep of all these five the sense.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Music, ho! music, such as charmeth sleep!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Now, when thou wakest, with thine own fool's eyes peep.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Sound, music! Come, my queen, take hands with me, And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be. Now thou and I are new in amity, And will to-morrow midnight solemnly Dance in Duke Theseus' house triumphantly, And bless it to all fair prosperity: There shall the pairs of faithful lovers be Wedded, with Theseus, all in jollity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Fairy king, attend, and mark: I do hear the morning lark.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Then, my queen, in silence sad, Trip we after the night's shade: We the globe can compass soon, Swifter than the wandering moon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Come, my lord, and in our flight Tell me how it came this night That I sleeping here was found With these mortals on the ground.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Go, one of you, find out the forester; For now our observation is perform'd; And since we have the vaward of the day, My love shall hear the music of my hounds. Uncouple in the western valley; let them go: Dispatch, I say, and find the forester. We will, fair queen, up to the mountain's top, And mark the musical confusion Of hounds and echo in conjunction.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I was with Hercules and Cadmus once, When in a wood of Crete they bay'd the bear With hounds of Sparta: never did I hear Such gallant chiding: for, besides the groves, The skies, the fountains, every region near Seem'd all one mutual cry: I never heard So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind, So flew'd, so sanded, and their heads are hung With ears that sweep away the morning dew; Crook-knee'd, and dew-lapp'd like Thessalian bulls; Slow in pursuit, but match'd in mouth like bells, Each under each. A cry more tuneable Was never holla'd to, nor cheer'd with horn, In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly: Judge when you hear. But, soft! what nymphs are these?

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: No doubt they rose up early to observe The rite of May, and hearing our intent, Came here in grace our solemnity. But speak, Egeus; is not this the day That Hermia should give answer of her choice?

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: It is, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns. Good morrow, friends. Saint Valentine is past: Begin these wood-birds but to couple now?

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Pardon, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: I pray you all, stand up. I know you two are rival enemies: How comes this gentle concord in the world, That hatred is so far from jealousy, To sleep by hate, and fear no enmity?

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: My lord, I shall reply amazedly, Half sleep, half waking: but as yet, I swear, I cannot truly say how I came here; But, as I think,--for truly would I speak, And now do I bethink me, so it is,-- I came with Hermia hither: our intent Was to be gone from Athens, where we might, Without the peril of the Athenian law.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Enough, enough, my lord; you have enough: I beg the law, the law, upon his head. They would have stolen away; they would, Demetrius, Thereby to have defeated you and me, You of your wife and me of my consent, Of my consent that she should be your wife.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: My lord, fair Helen told me of their stealth, Of this their purpose hither to this wood; And I in fury hither follow'd them, Fair Helena in fancy following me. But, my good lord, I wot not by what power,-- But by some power it is,--my love to Hermia, Melted as the snow, seems to me now As the remembrance of an idle gaud Which in my childhood I did dote upon; And all the faith, the virtue of my heart, The object and the pleasure of mine eye, Is only Helena. To her, my lord, Was I betroth'd ere I saw Hermia: But, like in sickness, did I loathe this food; But, as in health, come to my natural taste, Now I do wish it, love it, long for it, And will for evermore be true to it.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Fair lovers, you are fortunately met: Of this discourse we more will hear anon. Egeus, I will overbear your will; For in the temple by and by with us These couples shall eternally be knit: And, for the morning now is something worn, Our purposed hunting shall be set aside. Away with us to Athens; three and three, We'll hold a feast in great solemnity. Come, Hippolyta.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: These things seem small and undistinguishable,

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Methinks I see these things with parted eye, When every thing seems double.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: So methinks: And I have found Demetrius like a jewel, Mine own, and not mine own.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Are you sure That we are awake? It seems to me That yet we sleep, we dream. Do not you think The duke was here, and bid us follow him?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Yea; and my father.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: And Hippolyta.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: And he did bid us follow to the temple.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: Why, then, we are awake: let's follow him And by the way let us recount our dreams.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The same. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA lying asleep.
speech.text: When my cue comes, call me, and I will answer: my next is, 'Most fair Pyramus.' Heigh-ho! Peter Quince! Flute, the bellows-mender! Snout, the tinker! Starveling! God's my life, stolen hence, and left me asleep! I have had a most rare vision. I have had a dream, past the wit of man to say what dream it was: man is but an ass, if he go about to expound this dream. Methought I was--there is no man can tell what. Methought I was,--and methought I had,--but man is but a patched fool, if he will offer to say what methought I had. The eye of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not seen, man's hand is not able to taste, his tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report, what my dream was. I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of this dream: it shall be called Bottom's Dream, because it hath no bottom; and I will sing it in the latter end of a play, before the duke: peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall sing it at her death.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Have you sent to Bottom's house? is he come home yet?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt he is transported.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: If he come not, then the play is marred: it goes not forward, doth it?

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: It is not possible: you have not a man in all Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft man in Athens.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Yea and the best person too; and he is a very paramour for a sweet voice.

speech.stagedir: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: You must say 'paragon:' a paramour is, God bless us, a thing of naught.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and there is two or three lords and ladies more married: if our sport had gone forward, we had all been made men.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: O sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence a day during his life; he could not have 'scaped sixpence a day: an the duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I'll be hanged; he would have deserved it: sixpence a day in Pyramus, or nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Where are these lads? where are these hearts?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Bottom! O most courageous day! O most happy hour!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Masters, I am to discourse wonders: but ask me not what; for if I tell you, I am no true Athenian. I will tell you every thing, right as it fell out.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Let us hear, sweet Bottom.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.
speech.text: Not a word of me. All that I will tell you is, that the duke hath dined. Get your apparel together, good strings to your beards, new ribbons to your pumps; meet presently at the palace; every man look o'er his part; for the short and the long is, our play is preferred. In any case, let Thisby have clean linen; and let not him that plays the lion pair his nails, for they shall hang out for the lion's claws. And, most dear actors, eat no onions nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath; and I do not doubt but to hear them say, it is a sweet comedy. No more words: away! go, away!

scene.title: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: 'Tis strange my Theseus, that these lovers speak of.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: More strange than true: I never may believe These antique fables, nor these fairy toys. Lovers and madmen have such seething brains, Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend More than cool reason ever comprehends. The lunatic, the lover and the poet Are of imagination all compact: One sees more devils than vast hell can hold, That is, the madman: the lover, all as frantic, Sees Helen's beauty in a brow of Egypt: The poet's eye, in fine frenzy rolling, Doth glance from heaven to earth, from earth to heaven; And as imagination bodies forth The forms of things unknown, the poet's pen Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing A local habitation and a name. Such tricks hath strong imagination, That if it would but apprehend some joy, It comprehends some bringer of that joy; Or in the night, imagining some fear, How easy is a bush supposed a bear!

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: But all the story of the night told over, And all their minds transfigured so together, More witnesseth than fancy's images And grows to something of great constancy; But, howsoever, strange and admirable.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth. Joy, gentle friends! joy and fresh days of love Accompany your hearts!

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: More than to us Wait in your royal walks, your board, your bed!

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Come now; what masques, what dances shall we have, To wear away this long age of three hours Between our after-supper and bed-time? Where is our usual manager of mirth? What revels are in hand? Is there no play, To ease the anguish of a torturing hour? Call Philostrate.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Here, mighty Theseus.

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Say, what abridgement have you for this evening? What masque? what music? How shall we beguile The lazy time, if not with some delight?

speech.stagedir: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, PHILOSTRATE, Lords and Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: There is a brief how many sports are ripe: Make choice of which your highness will see first.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: 'The battle with the Centaurs, to be sung By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.' We'll none of that: that have I told my love, In glory of my kinsman Hercules. 'The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals, Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.' That is an old device; and it was play'd When I from Thebes came last a conqueror. 'The thrice three Muses mourning for the death Of Learning, late deceased in beggary.' That is some satire, keen and critical, Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony. 'A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus And his love Thisbe; very tragical mirth.' Merry and tragical! tedious and brief! That is, hot ice and wondrous strange snow. How shall we find the concord of this discord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long, Which is as brief as I have known a play; But by ten words, my lord, it is too long, Which makes it tedious; for in all the play There is not one word apt, one player fitted: And tragical, my noble lord, it is; For Pyramus therein doth kill himself. Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess, Made mine eyes water; but more merry tears The passion of loud laughter never shed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: What are they that do play it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Hard-handed men that work in Athens here, Which never labour'd in their minds till now, And now have toil'd their unbreathed memories With this same play, against your nuptial.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: And we will hear it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I will hear that play; For never anything can be amiss, When simpleness and duty tender it. Go, bring them in: and take your places, ladies.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I love not to see wretchedness o'er charged And duty in his service perishing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: He says they can do nothing in this kind.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: The kinder we, to give them thanks for nothing. Our sport shall be to take what they mistake: And what poor duty cannot do, noble respect Takes it in might, not merit. Where I have come, great clerks have purposed To greet me with premeditated welcomes; Where I have seen them shiver and look pale, Make periods in the midst of sentences, Throttle their practised accent in their fears And in conclusion dumbly have broke off, Not paying me a welcome. Trust me, sweet, Out of this silence yet I pick'd a welcome; And in the modesty of fearful duty I read as much as from the rattling tongue Of saucy and audacious eloquence. Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity In least speak most, to my capacity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: So please your grace, the Prologue is address'd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Let him approach.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: If we offend, it is with our good will. That you should think, we come not to offend, But with good will. To show our simple skill, That is the true beginning of our end. Consider then we come but in despite. We do not come as minding to contest you, Our true intent is. All for your delight We are not here. That you should here repent you, The actors are at hand and by their show You shall know all that you are like to know.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This fellow doth not stand upon points.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt; he knows not the stop. A good moral, my lord: it is not enough to speak, but to speak true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Indeed he hath played on his prologue like a child on a recorder; a sound, but not in government.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: His speech, was like a tangled chain; nothing impaired, but all disordered. Who is next?

speech.stagedir: Enter Pyramus and Thisbe, Wall, Moonshine, and Lion
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Gentles, perchance you wonder at this show; But wonder on, till truth make all things plain. This man is Pyramus, if you would know; This beauteous lady Thisby is certain. This man, with lime and rough-cast, doth present Wall, that vile Wall which did these lovers sunder; And through Wall's chink, poor souls, they are content To whisper. At the which let no man wonder. This man, with lanthorn, dog, and bush of thorn, Presenteth Moonshine; for, if you will know, By moonshine did these lovers think no scorn To meet at Ninus' tomb, there, there to woo. This grisly beast, which Lion hight by name, The trusty Thisby, coming first by night, Did scare away, or rather did affright; And, as she fled, her mantle she did fall, Which Lion vile with bloody mouth did stain. Anon comes Pyramus, sweet youth and tall, And finds his trusty Thisby's mantle slain: Whereat, with blade, with bloody blameful blade, He bravely broach'd is boiling bloody breast; And Thisby, tarrying in mulberry shade, His dagger drew, and died. For all the rest, Let Lion, Moonshine, Wall, and lovers twain At large discourse, while here they do remain.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Prologue, Thisbe, Lion, and Moonshine
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I wonder if the lion be to speak.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Prologue, Thisbe, Lion, and Moonshine
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: No wonder, my lord: one lion may, when many asses do.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Prologue, Thisbe, Lion, and Moonshine
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: In this same interlude it doth befall That I, one Snout by name, present a wall; And such a wall, as I would have you think, That had in it a crannied hole or chink, Through which the lovers, Pyramus and Thisby, Did whisper often very secretly. This loam, this rough-cast and this stone doth show That I am that same wall; the truth is so: And this the cranny is, right and sinister, Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Prologue, Thisbe, Lion, and Moonshine
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt Prologue, Thisbe, Lion, and Moonshine
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard discourse, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Pyramus draws near the wall: silence!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O grim-look'd night! O night with hue so black! O night, which ever art when day is not! O night, O night! alack, alack, alack, I fear my Thisby's promise is forgot! And thou, O wall, O sweet, O lovely wall, That stand'st between her father's ground and mine! Thou wall, O wall, O sweet and lovely wall, Show me thy chink, to blink through with mine eyne! Thanks, courteous wall: Jove shield thee well for this! But what see I? No Thisby do I see. O wicked wall, through whom I see no bliss! Cursed be thy stones for thus deceiving me!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: No, in truth, sir, he should not. 'Deceiving me' is Thisby's cue: she is to enter now, and I am to spy her through the wall. You shall see, it will fall pat as I told you. Yonder she comes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O wall, full often hast thou heard my moans, For parting my fair Pyramus and me! My cherry lips have often kiss'd thy stones, Thy stones with lime and hair knit up in thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I see a voice: now will I to the chink, To spy an I can hear my Thisby's face. Thisby!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: My love thou art, my love I think.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Think what thou wilt, I am thy lover's grace; And, like Limander, am I trusty still.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: And I like Helen, till the Fates me kill.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Not Shafalus to Procrus was so true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: As Shafalus to Procrus, I to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O kiss me through the hole of this vile wall!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I kiss the wall's hole, not your lips at all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Wilt thou at Ninny's tomb meet me straightway?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: 'Tide life, 'tide death, I come without delay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Thus have I, Wall, my part discharged so; And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Now is the mural down between the two neighbours.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: No remedy, my lord, when walls are so wilful to hear without warning.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: The best in this kind are but shadows; and the worst are no worse, if imagination amend them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: It must be your imagination then, and not theirs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: If we imagine no worse of them than they of themselves, they may pass for excellent men. Here come two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: You, ladies, you, whose gentle hearts do fear The smallest monstrous mouse that creeps on floor, May now perchance both quake and tremble here, When lion rough in wildest rage doth roar. Then know that I, one Snug the joiner, am A lion-fell, nor else no lion's dam; For, if I should as lion come in strife Into this place, 'twere pity on my life.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: A very gentle beast, of a good conscience.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: The very best at a beast, my lord, that e'er I saw.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This lion is a very fox for his valour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: True; and a goose for his discretion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Not so, my lord; for his valour cannot carry his discretion; and the fox carries the goose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This lanthorn doth the horned moon present;--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: He should have worn the horns on his head.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: He is no crescent, and his horns are invisible within the circumference.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This lanthorn doth the horned moon present; Myself the man i' the moon do seem to be.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This is the greatest error of all the rest: the man should be put into the lanthorn. How is it else the man i' the moon?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: He dares not come there for the candle; for, you see, it is already in snuff.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: I am aweary of this moon: would he would change!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: It appears, by his small light of discretion, that he is in the wane; but yet, in courtesy, in all reason, we must stay the time.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Proceed, Moon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: All that I have to say, is, to tell you that the lanthorn is the moon; I, the man in the moon; this thorn-bush, my thorn-bush; and this dog, my dog.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Why, all these should be in the lanthorn; for all these are in the moon. But, silence! here comes Thisbe.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This is old Ninny's tomb. Where is my love?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Oh--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Well roared, Lion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Well run, Thisbe.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Well shone, Moon. Truly, the moon shines with a good grace.

speech.stagedir: The Lion shakes Thisbe's mantle, and exit
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Well moused, Lion.

speech.stagedir: The Lion shakes Thisbe's mantle, and exit
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: And so the lion vanished.

speech.stagedir: The Lion shakes Thisbe's mantle, and exit
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: And then came Pyramus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Sweet Moon, I thank thee for thy sunny beams; I thank thee, Moon, for shining now so bright; For, by thy gracious, golden, glittering gleams, I trust to take of truest Thisby sight. But stay, O spite! But mark, poor knight, What dreadful dole is here! Eyes, do you see? How can it be? O dainty duck! O dear! Thy mantle good, What, stain'd with blood! Approach, ye Furies fell! O Fates, come, come, Cut thread and thrum; Quail, crush, conclude, and quell!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: This passion, and the death of a dear friend, would go near to make a man look sad.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Beshrew my heart, but I pity the man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: O wherefore, Nature, didst thou lions frame? Since lion vile hath here deflower'd my dear: Which is--no, no--which was the fairest dame That lived, that loved, that liked, that look'd with cheer. Come, tears, confound; Out, sword, and wound The pap of Pyramus; Ay, that left pap, Where heart doth hop: Thus die I, thus, thus, thus. Now am I dead, Now am I fled; My soul is in the sky: Tongue, lose thy light; Moon take thy flight: Now die, die, die, die, die.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: No die, but an ace, for him; for he is but one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Less than an ace, man; for he is dead; he is nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: With the help of a surgeon he might yet recover, and prove an ass.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: How chance Moonshine is gone before Thisbe comes back and finds her lover?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: She will find him by starlight. Here she comes; and her passion ends the play.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Methinks she should not use a long one for such a Pyramus: I hope she will be brief.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: She hath spied him already with those sweet eyes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: And thus she means, videlicet:--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Asleep, my love? What, dead, my dove? O Pyramus, arise! Speak, speak. Quite dumb? Dead, dead? A tomb Must cover thy sweet eyes. These My lips, This cherry nose, These yellow cowslip cheeks, Are gone, are gone: Lovers, make moan: His eyes were green as leeks. O Sisters Three, Come, come to me, With hands as pale as milk; Lay them in gore, Since you have shore With shears his thread of silk. Tongue, not a word: Come, trusty sword; Come, blade, my breast imbrue: And, farewell, friends; Thus Thisby ends: Adieu, adieu, adieu.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Ay, and Wall too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: No assure you; the wall is down that parted their fathers. Will it please you to see the epilogue, or to hear a Bergomask dance between two of our company?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: No epilogue, I pray you; for your play needs no excuse. Never excuse; for when the players are all dead, there needs none to be blamed. Marry, if he that writ it had played Pyramus and hanged himself in Thisbe's garter, it would have been a fine tragedy: and so it is, truly; and very notably discharged. But come, your Bergomask: let your epilogue alone. The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelve: Lovers, to bed; 'tis almost fairy time. I fear we shall out-sleep the coming morn As much as we this night have overwatch'd. This palpable-gross play hath well beguiled The heavy gait of night. Sweet friends, to bed. A fortnight hold we this solemnity, In nightly revels and new jollity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Now the hungry lion roars, And the wolf behowls the moon; Whilst the heavy ploughman snores, All with weary task fordone. Now the wasted brands do glow, Whilst the screech-owl, screeching loud, Puts the wretch that lies in woe In remembrance of a shroud. Now it is the time of night That the graves all gaping wide, Every one lets forth his sprite, In the church-way paths to glide: And we fairies, that do run By the triple Hecate's team, From the presence of the sun, Following darkness like a dream, Now are frolic: not a mouse Shall disturb this hallow'd house: I am sent with broom before, To sweep the dust behind the door.

speech.stagedir: Enter OBERON and TITANIA with their train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Through the house give gathering light, By the dead and drowsy fire: Every elf and fairy sprite Hop as light as bird from brier; And this ditty, after me, Sing, and dance it trippingly.

speech.stagedir: Enter OBERON and TITANIA with their train
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: First, rehearse your song by rote To each word a warbling note: Hand in hand, with fairy grace, Will we sing, and bless this place.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: Now, until the break of day, Through this house each fairy stray. To the best bride-bed will we, Which by us shall blessed be; And the issue there create Ever shall be fortunate. So shall all the couples three Ever true in loving be; And the blots of Nature's hand Shall not in their issue stand; Never mole, hare lip, nor scar, Nor mark prodigious, such as are Despised in nativity, Shall upon their children be. With this field-dew consecrate, Every fairy take his gait; And each several chamber bless, Through this palace, with sweet peace; And the owner of it blest Ever shall in safety rest. Trip away; make no stay; Meet me all by break of day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Athens. The palace of THESEUS.
speech.text: If we shadows have offended, Think but this, and all is mended, That you have but slumber'd here While these visions did appear. And this weak and idle theme, No more yielding but a dream, Gentles, do not reprehend: if you pardon, we will mend: And, as I am an honest Puck, If we have unearned luck Now to 'scape the serpent's tongue, We will make amends ere long; Else the Puck a liar call; So, good night unto you all. Give me your hands, if we be friends, And Robin shall restore amends.
